revised_title: Cerebrospinal Fluid Pressure Response to Acute Vascular Changes
tldr: The article investigates the cerebrospinal fluid pressure response to certain acute vascular changes using a cat perfusion technique. The authors found that an increase in caval pressure leads to a sustained rise in cerebrospinal fluid pressure, while a decrease in cardiac input results in a fall followed by a rise. These effects are mainly due to changes in central venous pressures and can be explained by the increase in regional intracraniovertebral venous sinus pressure. The study provides insights into the complex relationship between vascular variables and cerebrospinal fluid pressure in mammals.
